These two problems use composition of ordinary generating functions. Let {\cal A} be a task with a_0=0 and ordinary generating function A(x) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n x^n. Let {\cal B} be the task "split the interval [n] into nonempty intervals and perform {\cal A} on each interval." Then the ordinary generating function for {\cal B} is
B(x) = \frac{1}{1-A(x)}.
Suppose that we have n prospective jurors, each assigned a number. We want to split the jurors into some number of intervals (the first k_1 jurors, the next k_2 jurors and so on).
\item Use the composition result above to find the ordinary generating function B(x) for this process. (Hint: task {\cal A} is "do nothing.")
Find the value of b_n.
Give a combinatorial proof of your value in (b). (Hint: if you haven't yet done so, simplify your answer in (b) to a single term.)
Now, once we have split the people into groups, we want to do some further organization. We must choose a foreman, and then the remaining people will be designated as juror, alternate or dismissed. Find the generating function B(x) for the total process (splitting the pool and then assigning roles).

These three problems use composition of exponential generating functions. Let {\cal A} be a task with a_0=0 and exponential generating function A(x) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_n \frac{x^n}{n!}. Let {\cal B} be the task "partition [n] into nonempty subsets and perform {\cal A} on each subset." Then the exponential generating function for {\cal B} is
B(x) = e^{A(x)}.
Suppose that we have n employees. We want to partition them into some number of nonempty subsets. Use the composition result above to find a formula for the corresponding exponential generating function B(x). You should recognize this marvelous generating function.
Now, each subset will become a committee, so we need to elect a chair. Give the exponential generating function B(x) for the entire process (partitioning and then choosing a chair for each committee.)
Instead of forming a committee, we want to seat each group at a circular table.
Find the exponential generating function B(x) for this process.
Use B(x) to find the value of b_n. Be amazed at the simplicity of the answer for this complicated question!
